097/**
098 * Class illustrating use of {@link SQLXML} to operate on XML data.
099 *<p>
100 * This class also serves as the mapping class for a composite type
101 * {@code javatest.onexml}, the better to verify that {@link SQLData}
102 * input/output works too. That's why it has to implement SQLData.
103 *<p>
104 * Everything mentioning the type XML here needs a conditional implementor tag
105 * in case of being loaded into a PostgreSQL instance built without that type.
106 */
107@SQLAction(provides="postgresql_xml", install=
108    "SELECT CASE (SELECT 1 FROM pg_type WHERE typname = 'xml') WHEN 1" +
109    " THEN set_config('pljava.implementors', 'postgresql_xml,' || " +
110    " current_setting('pljava.implementors'), true) " +
111    "END"
112)
113
114@SQLAction(implementor="postgresql_ge_80400",
115    provides="postgresql_xml_ge84",
116    install=
117    "SELECT CASE (SELECT 1 FROM pg_type WHERE typname = 'xml') WHEN 1" +
118    " THEN set_config('pljava.implementors', 'postgresql_xml_ge84,' || " +
119    " current_setting('pljava.implementors'), true) " +
120    "END"
121)
122
123@SQLAction(implementor="postgresql_xml_ge84", requires="echoXMLParameter",
124    install=
125    "WITH" +
126    " s(how) AS (SELECT generate_series(1, 7))," +
127    " t(x) AS (" +
128    "  SELECT table_to_xml('pg_catalog.pg_operator', true, false, '')" +
129    " )," +
130    " r(howin, howout, isdoc) AS (" +
131    "  SELECT" +
132    "   i.how, o.how," +
133    "   javatest.echoxmlparameter(x, i.how, o.how) IS DOCUMENT" +
134    "  FROM" +
135    "   t, s AS i, s AS o" +
136    "  WHERE" +
137    "   NOT (i.how = 6 and o.how = 7)" + // 6->7 unreliable in some JREs
138    " ) " +
139    "SELECT" +
140    " CASE WHEN every(isdoc)" +
141    "  THEN javatest.logmessage('INFO', 'SQLXML echos succeeded')" +
142    "  ELSE javatest.logmessage('WARNING', 'SQLXML echos had problems')" +
143    " END " +
144    "FROM" +
145    " r"
146)
147
148@SQLAction(implementor="postgresql_xml_ge84", requires="proxiedXMLEcho",
149    install=
150    "WITH" +
151    " s(how) AS (SELECT unnest('{1,2,4,5,6,7}'::int[]))," +
152    " t(x) AS (" +
153    "  SELECT table_to_xml('pg_catalog.pg_operator', true, false, '')" +
154    " )," +
155    " r(how, isdoc) AS (" +
156    "  SELECT" +
157    "   how," +
158    "   javatest.proxiedxmlecho(x, how) IS DOCUMENT" +
159    "  FROM" +
160    "   t, s" +
161    " )" +
162    "SELECT" +
163    " CASE WHEN every(isdoc)" +
164    "  THEN javatest.logmessage('INFO', 'proxied SQLXML echos succeeded')" +
165    "  ELSE javatest.logmessage('WARNING'," +
166    "       'proxied SQLXML echos had problems')" +
167    " END " +
168    "FROM" +
169    " r"
170)
171
172@SQLAction(implementor="postgresql_xml_ge84", requires="lowLevelXMLEcho",
173    install={
174    "SELECT" +
175    " preparexmlschema('schematest', $$" +
176    "<xs:schema" +
177    " xmlns:xs='http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema'" +
178    " targetNamespace='urn:testme'" +
179    " elementFormDefault='qualified'>" +
180    " <xs:element name='row'>" +
181    "  <xs:complexType>" +
182    "   <xs:sequence>" +
183    "    <xs:element name='textcol' type='xs:string' nillable='true'/>" +
184    "    <xs:element name='intcol' type='xs:integer' nillable='true'/>" +
185    "   </xs:sequence>" +
186    "  </xs:complexType>" +
187    " </xs:element>" +
188    "</xs:schema>" +
189    "$$, 'http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema', 5)",
190
191    "WITH" +
192    " s(how) AS (SELECT unnest('{4,5,7}'::int[]))," +
193    " r(isdoc) AS (" +
194    " SELECT" +
195    "  javatest.lowlevelxmlecho(" +
196    "   query_to_xml(" +
197    "    'SELECT ''hi'' AS textcol, 1 AS intcol', true, true, 'urn:testme'"+
198    "   ), how, params) IS DOCUMENT" +
199    " FROM" +
200    "  s," +
201    "  (SELECT 'schematest' AS schema) AS params" +
202    " )" +
203    "SELECT" +
204    " CASE WHEN every(isdoc)" +
205    "  THEN javatest.logmessage('INFO', 'XML Schema tests succeeded')" +
206    "  ELSE javatest.logmessage('WARNING'," +
207    "       'XML Schema tests had problems')" +
208    " END " +
209    "FROM" +
210    " r"
211    }
212)

214@SQLAction(implementor="postgresql_xml",
215           requires={"prepareXMLTransform", "transformXML"},
216    install={
217        "REVOKE EXECUTE ON FUNCTION javatest.prepareXMLTransformWithJava" +
218        " (pg_catalog.varchar, pg_catalog.xml, integer, boolean," +
219        "  pg_catalog.RECORD)" +
220        " FROM PUBLIC",
221
222        "SELECT" +
223        " javatest.prepareXMLTransform('distinctElementNames'," +
224        "'<xsl:transform version=''1.0''" +
225        " xmlns:xsl=''http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform''" +
226        " xmlns:exsl=''http://exslt.org/common''" +
227        " xmlns:set=''http://exslt.org/sets''" +
228        " extension-element-prefixes=''exsl set''" +
229        ">" +
230        " <xsl:output method=''xml'' indent=''no''/>" +
231        " <xsl:template match=''/''>" +
232        "  <xsl:variable name=''enames''>" +
233        "   <xsl:for-each select=''//*''>" +
234        "    <ename><xsl:value-of select=''local-name()''/></ename>" +
235        "   </xsl:for-each>" +
236        "  </xsl:variable>" +
237        "  <xsl:for-each" +
238        "   select=''set:distinct(exsl:node-set($enames)/ename)''>" +
239        "   <xsl:sort select=''string()''/>" +
240        "   <den><xsl:value-of select=''.''/></den>" +
241        "  </xsl:for-each>" +
242        " </xsl:template>" +
243        "</xsl:transform>', 5, true)",
244
245        "SELECT" +
246        " javatest.prepareXMLTransformWithJava('getPLJavaVersion'," +
247        "'<xsl:transform version=''1.0''" +
248        " xmlns:xsl=''http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform''" +
249        " xmlns:java=''http://xml.apache.org/xalan/java''" +
250        " exclude-result-prefixes=''java''" +
251        ">" +
252        " <xsl:template match=''/''>" +
253        "  <xsl:value-of" +
254        "   select=''java:java.lang.System.getProperty(" +
255        "    \"org.postgresql.pljava.version\")''" +
256        "  />" +
257        " </xsl:template>" +
258        "</xsl:transform>', enableExtensionFunctions => true)",
259
260        "SELECT" +
261        " CASE WHEN" +
262        "  javatest.transformXML('distinctElementNames'," +
263        "   '<a><c/><e/><b/><b/><d/></a>', 5, 5)::text" +
264        "  =" +
265        "   '<den>a</den><den>b</den><den>c</den><den>d</den><den>e</den>'"+
266        "  THEN javatest.logmessage('INFO', 'XSLT 1.0 test succeeded')" +
267        "  ELSE javatest.logmessage('WARNING', 'XSLT 1.0 test failed')" +
268        " END",
269
270        "SELECT" +
271        " CASE WHEN" +
272        "  javatest.transformXML('getPLJavaVersion', '')::text" +
273        "  OPERATOR(pg_catalog.=) extversion" +
274        "  THEN javatest.logmessage('INFO', 'XSLT 1.0 with Java succeeded')" +
275        "  ELSE javatest.logmessage('WARNING', 'XSLT 1.0 with Java failed')" +
276        " END" +
277        " FROM pg_catalog.pg_extension" +
278        " WHERE extname = 'pljava'"
279    }
280)
281@MappedUDT(schema="javatest", name="onexml", structure="c1 xml",
282           implementor="postgresql_xml",
283           comment="A composite type mapped by the PassXML example class")
284public class PassXML implements SQLData
285{
286    static SQLXML s_sx;
287
288    static TransformerFactory s_tf = TransformerFactory.newInstance();
289
290    static Map<String,Templates> s_tpls = new HashMap<>();
291
292    static Map<String,Schema> s_schemas = new HashMap<>();
293
294    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml")
295    public static String inXMLoutString(SQLXML in) throws SQLException
296    {
297        return in.getString();
298    }
299
300    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml")
301    public static SQLXML inStringoutXML(String in) throws SQLException
302    {
303        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
304        SQLXML result = c.createSQLXML();
305        result.setString(in);
306        return result;
307    }
308
309    /**
310     * Echo an XML parameter back, exercising seven different ways
311     * (howin =&gt; 1-7) of reading an SQLXML object, and seven
312     * (howout =&gt; 1-7) of returning one.
313     *<p>
314     * If howin =&gt; 0, the XML parameter is simply saved in a static. It can
315     * be read in a subsequent call with sx =&gt; null, but only in the same
316     * transaction.
317     *<p>
318     * The "echoing" is done (in the {@code echoXML} method below) using a
319     * {@code Transformer}, that is, the "TrAX" Transformation API for XML
320     * supplied in Java. It illustrates how an identity {@code Transformer} can
321     * be used to get the XML content from the source to the result for any of
322     * the APIs selectable by howin and howout.
323     *<p>
324     * It also illustrates something else. When using StAX (6 for howin
325     * or howout) and XML of the {@code CONTENT} flavor (multiple top-level
326     * elements, characters outside the top element, etc.), it is easy to
327     * construct examples that fail. The fault is not really with the StAX API,
328     * nor with TrAX proper, but with the small handful of bridge classes that
329     * were added to the JRE with StAX's first appearance, to make it
330     * interoperate with TrAX. It is not that those classes completely overlook
331     * the {@code CONTENT} case: they make some efforts to handle it. Just not
332     * the right ones, and given the Java developers' usual reluctance to change
333     * such longstanding behavior, that's probably not getting fixed.
334     *<p>
335     * Moral: StAX is a nice API, have no fear to use it directly in
336     * freshly-developed code, but: when using TrAX, make every effort to supply
337     * a {@code Transformer} with {@code Source} and {@code Result} objects of
338     * <em>any</em> kind other than StAX.
339     */
340    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml",
341              provides="echoXMLParameter")
342    public static SQLXML echoXMLParameter(SQLXML sx, int howin, int howout)
343    throws SQLException
344    {
345        if ( null == sx )
346            sx = s_sx;
347        if ( 0 == howin )
348        {
349            s_sx = sx;
350            return null;
351        }
352        return echoSQLXML(sx, howin, howout);
353    }
354
355    /**
356     * Echo an XML parameter back, but with parameter and return types of
357     * PostgreSQL {@code text}.
358     *<p>
359     * The other version of this method needs a conditional implementor tag
360     * because it cannot be declared in a PostgreSQL instance that was built
361     * without {@code libxml} support and the PostgreSQL {@code XML} type.
362     * But this version can, simply by mapping the {@code SQLXML} parameter
363     * and return types to the SQL {@code text} type. The Java code is no
364     * different.
365     *<p>
366     * Note that it's possible for both declarations to coexist in PostgreSQL
367     * (because as far as it is concerned, their signatures are different), but
368     * these two Java methods cannot have the same name (because they differ
369     * only in annotations, not in the declared Java types). So, this one needs
370     * a slightly tweaked name, and a {@code name} attribute in the annotation
371     * so PostgreSQL sees the right name.
372     */
373    @Function(schema="javatest", name="echoXMLParameter", type="text")
374    public static SQLXML echoXMLParameter_(
375        @SQLType("text") SQLXML sx, int howin, int howout)
376    throws SQLException
377    {
378        return echoXMLParameter(sx, howin, howout);
379    }
380
381    /**
382     * "Echo" an XML parameter not by creating a new writable {@code SQLXML}
383     * object at all, but simply returning the passed-in readable one untouched.
384     */
385    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml")
386    public static SQLXML bounceXMLParameter(SQLXML sx) throws SQLException
387    {
388        return sx;
389    }
390
391    /**
392     * Just like {@link bounceXMLParameter} but with parameter and return typed
393     * as {@code text}, and so usable on a PostgreSQL instance lacking the XML
394     * type.
395     */
396    @Function(schema="javatest", type="text", name="bounceXMLParameter")
397    public static SQLXML bounceXMLParameter_(@SQLType("text") SQLXML sx)
398    throws SQLException
399    {
400        return sx;
401    }
402
403    /**
404     * Just like {@link bounceXMLParameter} but with the parameter typed as
405     * {@code text} and the return type left as XML, so functions as a cast.
406     *<p>
407     * Slower than the other cases, because it must verify that the input really
408     * is XML before blindly calling it a PostgreSQL XML type. But the speed
409     * compares respectably to PostgreSQL's own CAST(text AS xml), at least for
410     * larger values; I am seeing Java pull ahead right around 32kB of XML data
411     * and beat PG by a factor of 2 or better at sizes of 1 or 2 MB.
412     * Unsurprisingly, PG has the clear advantage when values are very short.
413     */
414    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml")
415    public static SQLXML castTextXML(@SQLType("text") SQLXML sx)
416    throws SQLException
417    {
418        return sx;
419    }
420
421    /**
422     * Precompile an XSL transform {@code source} and save it (for the
423     * current session) as {@code name}.
424     *<p>
425     * Each value of {@code how}, 1-7, selects a different way of presenting
426     * the {@code SQLXML} object to the XSL processor.
427     *<p>
428     * Passing {@code true} for {@code enableExtensionFunctions} allows the
429     * transform to use extensions that the Java XSLT implementation supports,
430     * such as functions from EXSLT. Those are disabled by default.
431     *<p>
432     * Out of the box, Java's transformers only support XSLT 1.0. See the S9
433     * example for more capabilities (at the cost of downloading the Saxon jar).
434     */
435    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml",
436              provides="prepareXMLTransform")
437    public static void prepareXMLTransform(String name, SQLXML source,
438        @SQLType(defaultValue="0") int how,
439        @SQLType(defaultValue="false") boolean enableExtensionFunctions,
440        @SQLType(defaultValue={}) ResultSet adjust)
441    throws SQLException
442    {
443        prepareXMLTransform(
444            name, source, how, enableExtensionFunctions, adjust, false);
445    }
446
447    /**
448     * Precompile an XSL transform {@code source} and save it (for the
449     * current session) as {@code name}, where the transform may call Java
450     * methods.
451     *<p>
452     * Otherwise identical to {@code prepareXMLTransform}, this version sets the
453     * {@code TransformerFactory}'s {@code extensionClassLoader} (to the same
454     * loader that loads this class), so the transform will be able to use
455     * xalan's Java call syntax to call any public Java methods that would be
456     * accessible to this class. (That can make a big difference in usefulness
457     * for the otherwise rather limited XSLT 1.0.)
458     *<p>
459     * This example function will be installed with {@code EXECUTE} permission
460     * revoked from {@code PUBLIC}, as it essentially confers the ability to
461     * create arbitrary new Java functions, so should only be granted to roles
462     * you would be willing to grant {@code USAGE ON LANGUAGE java}.
463     *<p>
464     * Because this function only prepares the transform, and
465     * {@link #transformXML transformXML} applies it, there is some division of
466     * labor in determining what limits apply to its behavior. The use of this
467     * method instead of {@code prepareXMLTransform} determines whether the
468     * transform is allowed to see external Java methods at all; it will be
469     * the policy permissions granted to {@code transformXML} that control what
470     * those methods can do when the transform is applied. For now, that method
471     * is defined in the trusted/sandboxed {@code java} language, so this
472     * function could reasonably be granted to any role with {@code USAGE} on
473     * {@code java}. If, by contrast, {@code transformXML} were declared in the
474     * 'untrusted' {@code javaU}, it would be prudent to allow only superusers
475     * access to this function, just as only they can {@code CREATE FUNCTION} in
476     * an untrusted language.
477     */
478    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml",
479              provides="prepareXMLTransform")
480    public static void prepareXMLTransformWithJava(String name, SQLXML source,
481        @SQLType(defaultValue="0") int how,
482        @SQLType(defaultValue="false") boolean enableExtensionFunctions,
483        @SQLType(defaultValue={}) ResultSet adjust)
484    throws SQLException
485    {
486        prepareXMLTransform(
487            name, source, how, enableExtensionFunctions, adjust, true);
488    }
489
490    private static void prepareXMLTransform(String name, SQLXML source, int how,
491        boolean enableExtensionFunctions, ResultSet adjust, boolean withJava)
492    throws SQLException
493    {
494        TransformerFactory tf = TransformerFactory.newInstance();
495        String exf =
496          "http://www.oracle.com/xml/jaxp/properties/enableExtensionFunctions";
497        String ecl = "jdk.xml.transform.extensionClassLoader";
498        Source src = sxToSource(source, how, adjust);
499        try
500        {
501            tf.setFeature(exf, enableExtensionFunctions);
502            if ( withJava )
503                tf.setAttribute(ecl, PassXML.class.getClassLoader());
504            s_tpls.put(name, tf.newTemplates(src));
505        }
506        catch ( TransformerException te )
507        {
508            throw new SQLException(
509                "Preparing XML transformation: " + te.getMessage(), te);
510        }
511    }
512
513    /**
514     * Transform some XML according to a named transform prepared with
515     * {@code prepareXMLTransform}.
516     *<p>
517     * Pass null for {@code transformName} to get a plain identity transform
518     * (not such an interesting thing to do, unless you also specify indenting).
519     */
520    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml",
521              provides="transformXML")
522    public static SQLXML transformXML(
523        String transformName, SQLXML source,
524        @SQLType(defaultValue="0") int howin,
525        @SQLType(defaultValue="0") int howout,
526        @SQLType(defaultValue={}) ResultSet adjust,
527        @SQLType(defaultValue="false") boolean indent,
528        @SQLType(defaultValue="4") int indentWidth)
529    throws SQLException
530    {
531        Templates tpl = null == transformName? null: s_tpls.get(transformName);
532        Source src = sxToSource(source, howin, adjust);
533
534        if ( indent  &&  0 == howout )
535            howout = 4; // transformer only indents if writing a StreamResult
536
537        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
538        SQLXML result = c.createSQLXML();
539        Result rlt = sxToResult(result, howout, adjust);
540
541        try
542        {
543            Transformer t =
544                null == tpl ? s_tf.newTransformer() : tpl.newTransformer();
545            /*
546             * For the non-SAX/StAX/DOM flavors of output, you're responsible
547             * for setting the Transformer to use the server encoding.
548             */
549            if ( rlt instanceof StreamResult )
550                t.setOutputProperty(ENCODING,
551                    System.getProperty("org.postgresql.server.encoding"));
552            else if ( indent )
553                logMessage("WARNING",
554                    "indent requested, but howout specifies a non-stream " +
555                    "Result type; no indenting will happen");
556
557            t.setOutputProperty("indent", indent ? "yes" : "no");
558            t.setOutputProperty(
559                "{http://xml.apache.org/xalan}indent-amount", "" + indentWidth);
560
561            t.transform(src, rlt);
562        }
563        catch ( TransformerException te )
564        {
565            throw new SQLException("Transforming XML: " + te.getMessage(), te);
566        }
567
568        return ensureClosed(rlt, result, howout);
569    }
570
571    /**
572     * Precompile a schema {@code source} in schema language {@code lang}
573     * and save it (for the current session) as {@code name}.
574     *<p>
575     * Each value of {@code how}, 1-7, selects a different way of presenting
576     * the {@code SQLXML} object to the schema parser.
577     *<p>
578     * The {@code lang} parameter is a URI that identifies a known schema
579     * language. The only language a Java runtime is required to support is
580     * W3C XML Schema 1.0, with URI {@code http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema}.
581     */
582    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml")
583    public static void prepareXMLSchema(
584        String name, SQLXML source, String lang, int how)
585    throws SQLException
586    {
587        try
588        {
589            s_schemas.put(name,
590                SchemaFactory.newInstance(lang)
591                .newSchema(sxToSource(source, how)));
592        }
593        catch ( SAXException e )
594        {
595            throw new SQLException(
596                "failed to prepare schema: " + e.getMessage(), e);
597        }
598    }
599
600    private static SQLXML echoSQLXML(SQLXML sx, int howin, int howout)
601    throws SQLException
602    {
603        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
604        SQLXML rx = c.createSQLXML();
605        Source src = sxToSource(sx, howin);
606        Result rlt = sxToResult(rx, howout);
607
608        try
609        {
610            Transformer t = s_tf.newTransformer();
611            /*
612             * For the non-SAX/StAX/DOM flavors of output, you're responsible
613             * for setting the Transformer to use the server encoding.
614             */
615            if ( howout < 5 )
616                t.setOutputProperty(ENCODING,
617                    System.getProperty("org.postgresql.server.encoding"));
618            t.transform(src, rlt);
619        }
620        catch ( TransformerException te )
621        {
622            throw new SQLException("XML transformation failed", te);
623        }
624
625        return ensureClosed(rlt, rx, howout);
626    }
627
628    /**
629     * Echo the XML parameter back, using lower-level manipulations than
630     * {@code echoXMLParameter}.
631     *<p>
632     * This illustrates how the simple use of {@code t.transform(src,rlt)}
633     * in {@code echoSQLXML} substitutes for a lot of fiddly case-by-case code,
634     * but when coding for a specific case, all the generality of {@code
635     * transform} may not be needed. It can be interesting to compare memory use
636     * when XML values are large.
637     *<p>
638     * This method has been revised to demonstrate, even for low-level
639     * manipulations, how much fiddliness can now be avoided through use of the
640     * {@link Adjusting.XML.SourceResult} class, and how to make adjustments to
641     * parsing restrictions by passing the optional row-typed parameter
642     * <em>adjust</em>, which defaults to an empty row. For example, passing
643     *<pre>
644     * adjust =&gt; (select a from
645     *            (true as allowdtd, true as expandentityreferences) as a)
646     *</pre>
647     * would allow a document that contains an internal DTD subset and uses
648     * entities defined there.
649     *<p>
650     * The older, pre-{@code SourceResult} code for doing low-level XML echo
651     * has been moved to the {@code oldSchoolLowLevelEcho} method below. It can
652     * still be exercised by calling this method, explicitly passing
653     * {@code adjust => NULL}.
654     */
655    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml_ge84",
656        provides="lowLevelXMLEcho")
657    public static SQLXML lowLevelXMLEcho(
658        SQLXML sx, int how, @SQLType(defaultValue={}) ResultSet adjust)
659    throws SQLException
660    {
661        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
662        SQLXML rx = c.createSQLXML();
663
664        if ( null == adjust )
665            return oldSchoolLowLevelEcho(rx, sx, how);
666
667        Adjusting.XML.SourceResult axsr =
668            rx.setResult(Adjusting.XML.SourceResult.class);
669
670        switch ( how )
671        {
672        /*
673         * The first four cases all present the content as unparsed bytes or
674         * characters, so there is nothing to adjust on the source side.
675         */
676        case 1:
677            axsr.set(new StreamSource(sx.getBinaryStream()));
678            break;
679        case 2:
680            axsr.set(new StreamSource(sx.getCharacterStream()));
681            break;
682        case 3:
683            axsr.set(sx.getString());
684            break;
685        case 4:
686            axsr.set(sx.getSource(StreamSource.class));
687            break;
688        /*
689         * The remaining cases present the content in parsed form, and therefore
690         * may involve parsers that can be adjusted according to the supplied
691         * preferences.
692         */
693        case 5:
694            axsr.set(applyAdjustments(adjust,
695                sx.getSource(Adjusting.XML.SAXSource.class)));
696            break;
697        case 6:
698            axsr.set(applyAdjustments(adjust,
699                sx.getSource(Adjusting.XML.StAXSource.class)));
700            break;
701        case 7:
702            axsr.set(applyAdjustments(adjust,
703                sx.getSource(Adjusting.XML.DOMSource.class)));
704            break;
705        default:
706            throw new SQLDataException(
707                "how must be 1-7 for lowLevelXMLEcho", "22003");
708        }
709
710        /*
711         * Adjustments can also be applied to the SourceResult itself, where
712         * they will affect any implicitly-created parser used to verify or
713         * re-encode the content, if it was supplied in unparsed form.
714         */
715        return applyAdjustments(adjust, axsr).get().getSQLXML();
716    }
717
718    /**
719     * Apply adjustments (supplied as a row type with a named column for each
720     * desired adjustment and its value) to an instance of
721     * {@link Adjusting.XML.Parsing}.
722     *<p>
723     * Column names in the <em>adjust</em> row are case-insensitive versions of
724     * the method names in {@link Adjusting.XML.Parsing}, and the value of each
725     * column should be of the appropriate type (at present, boolean for all of
726     * them).
727     * @param adjust A row type as described above, possibly of no columns if no
728     * adjustments are wanted
729     * @param axp An instance of Adjusting.XML.Parsing
730     * @return axp, after applying any adjustments
731     */
732    public static <T extends Adjusting.XML.Parsing<? super T>>
733    T applyAdjustments(ResultSet adjust, T axp)
734    throws SQLException
735    {
736        ResultSetMetaData rsmd = adjust.getMetaData();
737        int n = rsmd.getColumnCount();
738
739        for ( int i = 1; i <= n; ++i )
740        {
741            String k = rsmd.getColumnLabel(i);
742            if ( "allowDTD".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
743                axp.allowDTD(adjust.getBoolean(i));
744            else if ( "externalGeneralEntities".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
745                axp.externalGeneralEntities(adjust.getBoolean(i));
746            else if ( "externalParameterEntities".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
747                axp.externalParameterEntities(adjust.getBoolean(i));
748            else if ( "loadExternalDTD".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
749                axp.loadExternalDTD(adjust.getBoolean(i));
750            else if ( "xIncludeAware".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
751                axp.xIncludeAware(adjust.getBoolean(i));
752            else if ( "expandEntityReferences".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
753                axp.expandEntityReferences(adjust.getBoolean(i));
754            else if ( "elementAttributeLimit".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
755                axp.elementAttributeLimit(adjust.getInt(i));
756            else if ( "entityExpansionLimit".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
757                axp.entityExpansionLimit(adjust.getInt(i));
758            else if ( "entityReplacementLimit".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
759                axp.entityReplacementLimit(adjust.getInt(i));
760            else if ( "maxElementDepth".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
761                axp.maxElementDepth(adjust.getInt(i));
762            else if ( "maxGeneralEntitySizeLimit".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
763                axp.maxGeneralEntitySizeLimit(adjust.getInt(i));
764            else if ( "maxParameterEntitySizeLimit".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
765                axp.maxParameterEntitySizeLimit(adjust.getInt(i));
766            else if ( "maxXMLNameLimit".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
767                axp.maxXMLNameLimit(adjust.getInt(i));
768            else if ( "totalEntitySizeLimit".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
769                axp.totalEntitySizeLimit(adjust.getInt(i));
770            else if ( "accessExternalDTD".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
771                axp.accessExternalDTD(adjust.getString(i));
772            else if ( "accessExternalSchema".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
773                axp.accessExternalSchema(adjust.getString(i));
774            else if ( "schema".equalsIgnoreCase(k) )
775            {
776                try
777                {
778                    axp.schema(s_schemas.get(adjust.getString(i)));
779                }
780                catch (UnsupportedOperationException e)
781                {
782                }
783            }
784            else
785                throw new SQLDataException(
786                    "unrecognized name \"" + k + "\" for parser adjustment",
787                    "22000");
788        }
789        return axp;
790    }
791
792    /**
793     * An obsolescent example, showing what was required to copy from one
794     * {@code SQLXML} object to another, using the various supported APIs,
795     * without using {@link Adjusting.XML.SourceResult}, or at least without
796     * using it much. It is still used in case 4 to be sure of getting a
797     * {@code StreamResult} that matches the byte-or-character-ness of the
798     * {@code StreamSource}. How to handle that case without
799     * {@code SourceResult} is left as an exercise.
800     */
801    private static SQLXML oldSchoolLowLevelEcho(SQLXML rx, SQLXML sx, int how)
802    throws SQLException
803    {
804        try
805        {
806            switch ( how )
807            {
808            case 1:
809                InputStream is = sx.getBinaryStream();
810                OutputStream os = rx.setBinaryStream();
811                shovelBytes(is, os);
812                break;
813            case 2:
814                Reader r = sx.getCharacterStream();
815                Writer w = rx.setCharacterStream();
816                shovelChars(r, w);
817                break;
818            case 3:
819                rx.setString(sx.getString());
820                break;
821            case 4:
822                StreamSource ss = sx.getSource(StreamSource.class);
823                Adjusting.XML.StreamResult sr =
824                    rx.setResult(Adjusting.XML.StreamResult.class);
825                is = ss.getInputStream();
826                r  = ss.getReader();
827                if ( null != is )
828                {
829                    os = sr.preferBinaryStream().get().getOutputStream();
830                    shovelBytes(is, os);
831                    break;
832                }
833                if ( null != r )
834                {
835                    w  = sr.preferCharacterStream().get().getWriter();
836                    shovelChars(r, w);
837                    break;
838                }
839                throw new SQLDataException(
840                    "StreamSource contained neither InputStream nor Reader");
841            case 5:
842                SAXSource sxs = sx.getSource(SAXSource.class);
843                SAXResult sxr = rx.setResult(SAXResult.class);
844                XMLReader xr  = sxs.getXMLReader();
845                if ( null == xr )
846                {
847                    SAXParserFactory spf = SAXParserFactory.newInstance();
848                    spf.setNamespaceAware(true);
849                    xr = spf.newSAXParser().getXMLReader();
850                    /*
851                     * Important: before copying this example code for another
852                     * use, consider whether the input XML might be untrusted.
853                     * If so, the new XMLReader created here should have several
854                     * features given safe default settings as outlined in the
855                     * OWASP guidelines. (This branch is not reached when sx is
856                     * a PL/Java native SQLXML instance, as xr will be non-null
857                     * and already configured.)
858                     */
859                }
860                ContentHandler ch = sxr.getHandler();
861                xr.setContentHandler(ch);
862                if ( ch instanceof DTDHandler )
863                    xr.setDTDHandler((DTDHandler)ch);
864                LexicalHandler lh = sxr.getLexicalHandler();
865                if ( null == lh  &&  ch instanceof LexicalHandler )
866                lh = (LexicalHandler)ch;
867                if ( null != lh )
868                    xr.setProperty(
869                        "http://xml.org/sax/properties/lexical-handler", lh);
870                xr.parse(sxs.getInputSource());
871                break;
872            case 6:
873                StAXSource sts = sx.getSource(StAXSource.class);
874                StAXResult str = rx.setResult(StAXResult.class);
875                XMLOutputFactory xof = XMLOutputFactory.newInstance();
876                /*
877                 * The Source has either an event reader or a stream reader. Use
878                 * the event reader directly, or create one around the stream
879                 * reader.
880                 */
881                XMLEventReader xer = sts.getXMLEventReader();
882                if ( null == xer )
883                {
884                    XMLInputFactory  xif = XMLInputFactory .newInstance();
885                    xif.setProperty(xif.IS_NAMESPACE_AWARE, true);
886                    /*
887                     * Important: before copying this example code for another
888                     * use, consider whether the input XML might be untrusted.
889                     * If so, the new XMLInputFactory created here might want
890                     * several properties given safe default settings as
891                     * outlined in the OWASP guidelines. (When sx is a PL/Java
892                     * native SQLXML instance, the XMLStreamReader obtained
893                     * below will already have been so configured.)
894                     */
895                    xer = xif.createXMLEventReader(sts.getXMLStreamReader());
896                }
897                /*
898                 * Were you thinking the above could be simply
899                 * createXMLEventReader(sts) by analogy with the writer below?
900                 * Good thought, but the XMLInputFactory implementation that's
901                 * included in OpenJDK doesn't implement the case where the
902                 * Source argument is a StAXSource! Two lines would do it.
903                 */
904                /*
905                 * Because of a regression in Java 9 and later, the line below,
906                 * while working in Java 8 and earlier, will produce a
907                 * ClassCastException in Java 9 through (for sure) 12, (almost
908                 * certainly) 13, and on until some future version fixes the
909                 * regression, if ever, if 'str' wraps any XMLStreamWriter
910                 * implementation other than the inaccessible one from the guts
911                 * of the JDK itself. The bug has been reported but (as of this
912                 * writing) is still in the maddening limbo phase of the Java
913                 * bug reporting cycle, where no bug number can refer to it. See
914                 * lowLevelXMLEcho() above for code to do this copy successfully
915                 * using an Adjusting.XML.SourceResult.
916                 */
917                XMLEventWriter xew = xof.createXMLEventWriter(str);
918                xew.add(xer);
919                xew.close();
920                xer.close();
921                break;
922            case 7:
923                DOMSource ds = sx.getSource(DOMSource.class);
924                DOMResult dr = rx.setResult(DOMResult.class);
925                dr.setNode(ds.getNode());
926                break;
927            default:
928                throw new SQLDataException(
929                    "how must be 1-7 for lowLevelXMLEcho", "22003");
930            }
931        }
932        catch ( IOException e )
933        {
934            throw new SQLException(
935                "IOException in lowLevelXMLEcho", "58030", e);
936        }
937        catch (
938            ParserConfigurationException | SAXException | XMLStreamException e )
939        {
940            throw new SQLException(
941                "XML exception in lowLevelXMLEcho", "22000", e);
942        }
943        return rx;
944    }
945
946    /**
947     * Proxy a PL/Java SQLXML source object as if it were of a non-PL/Java
948     * implementing class, to confirm that it can still be returned successfully
949     * to PostgreSQL.
950     * @param sx readable {@code SQLXML} object to proxy
951     * @param how 1,2,4,5,6,7 determines what subclass of {@code Source} will be
952     * returned by {@code getSource}.
953     */
954    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml",
955              provides="proxiedXMLEcho")
956    public static SQLXML proxiedXMLEcho(SQLXML sx, int how)
957    throws SQLException
958    {
959        return new SQLXMLProxy(sx, how);
960    }

962    /**

965     * should begin with an XML Decl that names the encoding.
966     *<p>

971    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml",
972              provides="mockedXMLEchoB")
973    public static SQLXML mockedXMLEcho(byte[] bytes)
974    throws SQLException
975    {
976        return new SQLXMLMock(bytes);

997    /**
998     * Text-typed variant of lowLevelXMLEcho (does not require XML type).
999     *<p>
1000     * It does declare a parameter default, limiting it to PostgreSQL 8.4 or
1001     * later.
1002     */
1003    @Function(schema="javatest", name="lowLevelXMLEcho",
1004        type="text", implementor="postgresql_ge_80400")
1005    public static SQLXML lowLevelXMLEcho_(@SQLType("text") SQLXML sx, int how,
1006        @SQLType(defaultValue={}) ResultSet adjust)
1007    throws SQLException
1008    {

1012    /**
1013     * Low-level XML echo where the Java parameter and return type are String.
1014     */
1015    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml", type="xml")
1016    public static String lowLevelXMLEcho(@SQLType("xml") String x)
1017    throws SQLException
1018    {
1019        return x;
1020    }
1021
1022    /**
1023     * Create some XML, pass it to a {@code SELECT ?} prepared statement,
1024     * retrieve it from the result set, and return it via the out-parameter
1025     * result set of this {@code RECORD}-returning function.
1026     */
1027    @Function(schema="javatest", type="RECORD")
1028    public static boolean xmlInStmtAndRS(ResultSet out) throws SQLException
1029    {
1030        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
1031        SQLXML x = c.createSQLXML();
1032        x.setString("<a/>");
1033        PreparedStatement ps = c.prepareStatement("SELECT ?");
1034        ps.setObject(1, x, Types.SQLXML);
1035        ResultSet rs = ps.executeQuery();
1036        rs.next();
1037        if ( Types.SQLXML != rs.getMetaData().getColumnType(1) )
1038            logMessage("WARNING",
1039                "ResultSetMetaData.getColumnType() misreports SQLXML");
1040        x = rs.getSQLXML(1);
1041        ps.close();
1042        out.updateObject(1, x);
1043        return true;
1044    }
1045
1046    /**
1047     * Test serialization into the PostgreSQL server encoding by returning
1048     * a text node, optionally wrapped in an element, containing the supplied
1049     * stuff.
1050     *<p>
1051     * The stuff is supplied as a {@code bytea} and a named <em>encoding</em>,
1052     * so it is easy to supply stuff that isn't in the server encoding and see
1053     * what the serializer does with it.
1054     *<p>
1055     * As of this writing, if the <em>stuff</em>, decoded according to
1056     * <em>encoding</em>, contains characters that are not representable in the
1057     * server encoding, the serializers supplied in the JRE will:
1058     *<ul>
1059     *<li>SAX, DOM: replace the character with a numeric character reference if
1060     * the node is wrapped in an element, but not outside of an element; there,
1061     * PL/Java ensures an {@code UnmappableCharacterException} is thrown, as the
1062     * serializer would otherwise silently lose information by replacing the
1063     * character with a {@code ?}.
1064     *<li>StAX: replace the character with a numeric character reference whether
1065     * wrapped in an element or not (outside of an element, this officially
1066     * violates the letter of the XML spec, but does not lose information, and
1067     * is closer to the spirit of SQL/XML with its {@code XML(CONTENT)} type).
1068     *</ul>
1069     * @param stuff Content to be used in the text node
1070     * @param encoding Name of an encoding; stuff will be decoded to Unicode
1071     * according to this encoding, and then serialized into the server encoding,
1072     * where possible.
1073     * @param how Integer specifying which XML API to test, like every other how
1074     * in this class; here the only valid choices are 5 (SAX), 6 (StAX), or
1075     * 7 (DOM).
1076     * @param inElement True if the text node should be wrapped in an element.
1077     * @return The resulting XML content.
1078     */
1079    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml")
1080    public static SQLXML xmlTextNode(
1081        byte[] stuff, String encoding, int how, boolean inElement)
1082        throws Exception
1083    {
1084        if ( 5 > how || how > 7 )
1085            throw new SQLDataException(
1086                "how must be 5-7 for xmlTextNode", "22003");
1087
1088        String stuffString = new String(stuff, encoding);
1089        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
1090        SQLXML rx = c.createSQLXML();
1091
1092        switch ( how )
1093        {
1094        case 5:
1095            SAXResult sxr = rx.setResult(SAXResult.class);
1096            sxr.getHandler().startDocument();
1097            if ( inElement )
1098                sxr.getHandler().startElement("", "sax", "sax",
1099                    new AttributesImpl());
1100            sxr.getHandler().characters(
1101                stuffString.toCharArray(), 0, stuffString.length());
1102            if ( inElement )
1103                sxr.getHandler().endElement("", "sax", "sax");
1104            sxr.getHandler().endDocument();
1105            break;
1106        case 6:
1107            StAXResult stxr = rx.setResult(StAXResult.class);
1108            stxr.getXMLStreamWriter().writeStartDocument();
1109            if ( inElement )
1110                stxr.getXMLStreamWriter().writeStartElement("", "stax", "");
1111            stxr.getXMLStreamWriter().writeCharacters(stuffString);
1112            if ( inElement )
1113                stxr.getXMLStreamWriter().writeEndElement();
1114            stxr.getXMLStreamWriter().writeEndDocument();
1115            break;
1116        case 7:
1117            DOMResult dr = rx.setResult(DOMResult.class);
1118            /*
1119             * Why request features XML and Traversal?
1120             * If the only features requested are from the set
1121             * {Core, XML, LS} and maybe XPath, you get a brain-damaged
1122             * DOMImplementation that violates the org.w3c.dom.DOMImplementation
1123             * contract, as createDocument still tries to make a document
1124             * element even when passed null,null,null when, according to the
1125             * contract, it should not. To get the real implementation that
1126             * works, ask for some feature it supports outside of that core set.
1127             * I don't really need Traversal, but by asking for it, I get what
1128             * I do need.
1129             */
1130            Document d = DOMImplementationRegistry.newInstance()
1131                .getDOMImplementation("XML Traversal")
1132                .createDocument(null, null, null);
1133            DocumentFragment df = d.createDocumentFragment();
1134            ( inElement ? df.appendChild(d.createElement("dom")) : df )
1135                .appendChild(d.createTextNode(stuffString));
1136            dr.setNode(df);
1137            break;
1138        }
1139        return rx;
1140    }
1141
1142    /**
1143     * Create and leave some number of SQLXML objects unclosed, unused, and
1144     * unreferenced, as a test of reclamation.
1145     * @param howmany Number of SQLXML instances to create.
1146     * @param how If nonzero, the flavor of writing to request on the object
1147     * before abandoning it; if zero, it is left in its initial, writable state.
1148     */
1149    @Function(schema="javatest")
1150    public static void unclosedSQLXML(int howmany, int how) throws SQLException
1151    {
1152        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
1153        while ( howmany --> 0 )
1154        {
1155            SQLXML sx = c.createSQLXML();
1156            if ( 0 < how )
1157                sxToResult(sx, how);
1158        }
1159    }
1160
1161
1162    /**
1163     * Return some instance of {@code Source} for reading an {@code SQLXML}
1164     * object, depending on the parameter {@code how}.
1165     *<p>
1166     * Note that this method always returns a {@code Source}, even for cases
1167     * 1 and 2 (obtaining readable streams directly from the {@code SQLXML}
1168     * object; this method wraps them in {@code Source}), and case 3
1169     * ({@code getString}; this method creates a {@code StringReader} and
1170     * returns it wrapped in a {@code Source}.
1171     */
1172    private static Source sxToSource(SQLXML sx, int how) throws SQLException
1173    {
1174        switch ( how )
1175        {
1176            case  1: return new StreamSource(sx.getBinaryStream());
1177            case  2: return new StreamSource(sx.getCharacterStream());
1178            case  3: return new StreamSource(new StringReader(sx.getString()));
1179            case  4: return     sx.getSource(StreamSource.class);
1180            case  5: return     sx.getSource(SAXSource.class);
1181            case  6: return     sx.getSource(StAXSource.class);
1182            case  7: return     sx.getSource(DOMSource.class);
1183            default: throw new SQLDataException("how should be 1-7", "22003");
1184        }
1185    }
1186
1187    /**
1188     * Return some instance of {@code Result} for writing an {@code SQLXML}
1189     * object, depending on the parameter {@code how}.
1190     *<p>
1191     * Note that this method always returns a {@code Result}, even for cases
1192     * 1 and 2 (obtaining writable streams directly from the {@code SQLXML}
1193     * object; this method wraps them in {@code Result}), and case 3
1194     * ({@code setString}; this method creates a {@code StringWriter} and
1195     * returns it wrapped in a {@code Result}.
1196     *<p>
1197     * In case 3, it will be necessary, after writing, to get the {@code String}
1198     * from the {@code StringWriter}, and call {@code setString} with it.
1199     */
1200    private static Result sxToResult(SQLXML sx, int how) throws SQLException
1201    {
1202        switch ( how )
1203        {
1204            case  1: return new StreamResult(sx.setBinaryStream());
1205            case  2: return new StreamResult(sx.setCharacterStream());
1206            case  3: return new StreamResult(new StringWriter());
1207            case  4: return     sx.setResult(StreamResult.class);
1208            case  5: return     sx.setResult(SAXResult.class);
1209            case  6: return     sx.setResult(StAXResult.class);
1210            case  7:
1211                DOMResult r = sx.setResult(DOMResult.class);
1212                allowFragment(r); // else it'll accept only DOCUMENT form
1213                return r;
1214            default: throw new SQLDataException("how should be 1-7", "22003");
1215        }
1216    }
1217
1218    /**
1219     * Return some instance of {@code Source} for reading an {@code SQLXML}
1220     * object, depending on the parameter {@code how}, applying any adjustments
1221     * in {@code adjust}.
1222     *<p>
1223     * Allows {@code how} to be zero, meaning to let the implementation choose
1224     * what kind of {@code Source} to present. Otherwise identical to the other
1225     * {@code sxToSource}.
1226     */
1227    private static Source sxToSource(SQLXML sx, int how, ResultSet adjust)
1228    throws SQLException
1229    {
1230        Source s;
1231        switch ( how )
1232        {
1233            case  0: s = sx.getSource(Adjusting.XML.Source.class); break;
1234            case  1:
1235            case  2:
1236            case  3:
1237            case  4:
1238                return sxToSource(sx, how); // no adjustments on a StreamSource
1239            case  5: s = sx.getSource(Adjusting.XML.SAXSource.class); break;
1240            case  6: s = sx.getSource(Adjusting.XML.StAXSource.class); break;
1241            case  7: s = sx.getSource(Adjusting.XML.DOMSource.class); break;
1242            default: throw new SQLDataException("how should be 0-7", "22003");
1243        }
1244
1245        if ( s instanceof Adjusting.XML.Source )
1246            return applyAdjustments(adjust, (Adjusting.XML.Source<?>)s).get();
1247        return s;
1248    }
1249
1250    /**
1251     * Return some instance of {@code Result} for writing an {@code SQLXML}
1252     * object, depending on the parameter {@code how} applying any adjustments
1253     * in {@code adjust}.
1254     *<p>
1255     * Allows {@code how} to be zero, meaning to let the implementation choose
1256     * what kind of {@code Result} to present. Otherwise identical to the other
1257     * {@code sxToResult}.
1258     */
1259    private static Result sxToResult(SQLXML sx, int how, ResultSet adjust)
1260    throws SQLException
1261    {
1262        Result r;
1263        switch ( how )
1264        {
1265            case  1: // you might wish you could adjust a raw BinaryStream
1266            case  2: // or CharacterStream
1267            case  3: // or String, but you can't. Ask for a StreamResult.
1268            case  5: // SAXResult needs no adjustment
1269            case  6: // StAXResult needs no adjustment
1270            case  7: // DOMResult needs no adjustment
1271                return sxToResult(sx, how);
1272            case  4: r = sx.setResult(Adjusting.XML.StreamResult.class); break;
1273            case  0: r = sx.setResult(Adjusting.XML.Result.class); break;
1274            default: throw new SQLDataException("how should be 0-7", "22003");
1275        }
1276
1277        if ( r instanceof Adjusting.XML.Result )
1278            return applyAdjustments(adjust, (Adjusting.XML.Result<?>)r).get();
1279        return r;
1280    }
1281
1282    /**
1283     * Ensure the closing of whatever method was used to add content to
1284     * an {@code SQLXML} object.
1285     *<p>
1286     * Before a {@code SQLXML} object that has been written to can be used by
1287     * PostgreSQL (returned as a function result, plugged in as a prepared
1288     * statement parameter or into a {@code ResultSet}, etc.), the method used
1289     * for writing it must be "closed" to ensure the writing is complete.
1290     *<p>
1291     * If it is set with {@link SQLXML#setString setString}, nothing more is
1292     * needed; {@code setString} obviously sets the whole value at once. Any
1293     * {@code OutputStream} or {@code Writer} obtained from
1294     * {@link SQLXML#setBinaryStream setBinaryStream} or
1295     * {@link SQLXML#setCharacterStream setCharacterStream}, or from
1296     * {@link SQLXML#setResult setResult}{@code (StreamResult.class)}, has to be
1297     * explicitly closed (a {@link Transformer} does not close its
1298     * {@link Result} when the transformation is complete!).
1299     * Those are cases 1, 2, and 4 here.
1300     *<p>
1301     * Cases 5 ({@code SAXResult}) and 6 ({@code StAXResult}) need no special
1302     * attention; though the {@code Transformer} does not close them, the ones
1303     * returned by this {@code SQLXML} implementation are set up to close
1304     * themselves when the {@code endDocument} event is written.
1305     *<p>
1306     * Case 3 (test of {@code setString} is handled specially here. As this
1307     * class allows testing of all techniques for writing the {@code SQLXML}
1308     * object, and most of those involve a {@code Result}, case 3 is handled
1309     * by also constructing a {@code Result} over a {@link StringWriter} and
1310     * having the content written into that; this method then extracts the
1311     * content from the {@code StringWriter} and passes it to {@code setString}.
1312     * For cases 1 and 2, likewise, the stream obtained with
1313     * {@code getBinaryStream} or {@code getCharacterStream} has been wrapped in
1314     * a {@code Result} for generality in this example.
1315     *<p>
1316     * A typical application will not need the generality seen here; it
1317     * will usually know which technique it is using to write the {@code SQLXML}
1318     * object, and only needs to know how to close that if it needs closing.
1319     * @param r The {@code Result} onto which writing was done.
1320     * @param sx The {@code SQLXML} object being written.
1321     * @param how The integer used in this example class to select which method
1322     * of writing the {@code SQLXML} object was to be tested.
1323     * @return The {@code SQLXML} object {@code sx}, because why not?
1324     */
1325    public static SQLXML ensureClosed(Result r, SQLXML sx, int how)
1326    throws SQLException
1327    {
1328        switch ( how )
1329        {
1330        case 1:
1331        case 2:
1332        case 4:
1333            StreamResult sr = (StreamResult)r;
1334            OutputStream os = sr.getOutputStream();
1335            Writer w = sr.getWriter();
1336            try
1337            {
1338                if ( null != os )
1339                    os.close();
1340                if ( null != w )
1341                    w.close();
1342            }
1343            catch ( IOException ioe )
1344            {
1345                throw new SQLException(
1346                    "Failure closing SQLXML result", "XX000");
1347            }
1348            break;
1349        case 3:
1350            StringWriter sw = (StringWriter)((StreamResult)r).getWriter();
1351            String s = sw.toString();
1352            sx.setString(s);
1353            break;
1354        }
1355        return sx;
1356    }
1357
1358    /**
1359     * Configure a {@code DOMResult} to accept {@code CONTENT} (a/k/a
1360     * document fragment), not only the more restrictive {@code DOCUMENT}.
1361     *<p>
1362     * The other forms of {@code Result} that can be requested will happily
1363     * accept {@code XML(CONTENT)} and not just {@code XML(DOCUMENT)}.
1364     * The {@code DOMResult} is pickier, however: if you first call
1365     * {@link DOMResult#setNode setNode} with a {@code DocumentFragment}, it
1366     * will accept either form, but if you leave the node unset when passing the
1367     * {@code DOMResult} to a transformer, the transformer will default to
1368     * putting a {@code Document} node there, and then it will not accept a
1369     * fragment.
1370     *<p>
1371     * If you need to handle fragments, this method illustrates how to pre-load
1372     * the {@code DOMResult} with an empty {@code DocumentFragment}. Note that
1373     * if you use some XML processing package that supplies its own classes
1374     * implementing DOM nodes, you may need to use a {@code DocumentFragment}
1375     * instance obtained from that package.
1376     */
1377    public static void allowFragment(DOMResult r) throws SQLException
1378    {
1379        try
1380        {
1381            r.setNode(DocumentBuilderFactory.newInstance()
1382                .newDocumentBuilder().newDocument()
1383                    .createDocumentFragment());
1384        }
1385        catch ( ParserConfigurationException pce )
1386        {
1387            throw new SQLException("Failed initializing DOMResult", pce);
1388        }
1389    }
1390
1391    private static void shovelBytes(InputStream is, OutputStream os)
1392    throws IOException
1393    {
1394        byte[] b = new byte[8192];
1395        int got;
1396        while ( -1 != (got = is.read(b)) )
1397            os.write(b, 0, got);
1398        is.close();
1399        os.close();
1400    }
1401
1402    private static void shovelChars(Reader r, Writer w)
1403    throws IOException
1404    {
1405        char[] b = new char[8192];
1406        int got;
1407        while ( -1 != (got = r.read(b)) )
1408            w.write(b, 0, got);
1409        r.close();
1410        w.close();
1411    }
1412
1413    /**
1414     * Test the MappedUDT (in one direction anyway).
1415     *<p>
1416     * Creates a {@code PassXML} object, the Java class that maps the
1417     * {@code javatest.onexml} composite type, which has one member, of XML
1418     * type. Stores a {@code SQLXML} value in that field of the {@code PassXML}
1419     * object, and passes that to an SQL query that expects and returns
1420     * {@code javatest.onexml}. Retrieves the XML from the value field of the
1421     * {@code PassXML} object created to map the result of the query.
1422     * @return The original XML value, if all goes well.
1423     */
1424    @Function(schema="javatest", implementor="postgresql_xml")
1425    public static SQLXML xmlFromComposite() throws SQLException
1426    {
1427        Connection c = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
1428        PreparedStatement ps =
1429            c.prepareStatement("SELECT CAST(? AS javatest.onexml)");
1430        SQLXML x = c.createSQLXML();
1431        x.setString("<a/>");
1432        PassXML obj = new PassXML();
1433        obj.m_value = x;
1434        obj.m_typeName = "javatest.onexml";
1435        ps.setObject(1, obj);
1436        ResultSet r = ps.executeQuery();
1437        r.next();
1438        obj = (PassXML)r.getObject(1);
1439        ps.close();
1440        return obj.m_value;
1441    }
1442
1443    /*
1444     * Required to serve as a MappedUDT:
1445     */
1446    /**
1447     * No-arg constructor required of objects that will implement
1448     * {@link SQLData}.
1449     */
1450    public PassXML() { }
1451
1452    private String m_typeName;
1453    private SQLXML m_value;
1454
1455    @Override
1456    public String getSQLTypeName() { return m_typeName; }
1457
1458    @Override
1459    public void readSQL(SQLInput stream, String typeName) throws SQLException
1460    {
1461        m_typeName = typeName;
1462        m_value = (SQLXML) stream.readObject();
1463    }
1464
1465    @Override
1466    public void writeSQL(SQLOutput stream) throws SQLException
1467    {
1468        stream.writeSQLXML(m_value);
1469    }
1470
1471    /**
1472     * Class that will proxy methods to another {@code SQLXML} class.
1473     *<p>
1474     * Used for testing the PL/Java can accept input for PostgreSQL from an
1475     * {@code SQLXML} object not of its own implementation (for example, one
1476     * obtained from a different JDBC driver from some other database).
1477     *<p>
1478     * Only the {@code getSource} method is specially treated, to allow
1479     * exercising the various flavors of source.
1480     */
1481    public static class SQLXMLProxy implements SQLXML
1482    {
1483        private SQLXML m_sx;
1484        private int m_how;
1485
1486        public SQLXMLProxy(SQLXML sx, int how)
1487        {
1488            if ( null == sx )
1489                throw new NullPointerException("Null SQLXMLProxy target");
1490            if ( 1 > how  ||  how > 7  ||  how == 3 )
1491                throw new IllegalArgumentException(
1492                    "\"how\" must be 1, 2, 4, 5, 6, or 7");
1493            m_sx = sx;
1494            m_how = how;
1495        }
1496
1497        @Override
1498        public void free() throws SQLException { m_sx.free(); }
1499
1500        @Override
1501        public InputStream getBinaryStream() throws SQLException
1502        {
1503            return m_sx.getBinaryStream();
1504        }
1505
1506        @Override
1507        public OutputStream setBinaryStream() throws SQLException
1508        {
1509            return m_sx.setBinaryStream();
1510        }
1511
1512        @Override
1513        public Reader getCharacterStream() throws SQLException
1514        {
1515            return m_sx.getCharacterStream();
1516        }
1517
1518        @Override
1519        public Writer setCharacterStream() throws SQLException
1520        {
1521            return m_sx.setCharacterStream();
1522        }
1523
1524        @Override
1525        public String getString() throws SQLException
1526        {
1527            return m_sx.getString();
1528        }
1529
1530        @Override
1531        public void setString(String value) throws SQLException
1532        {
1533            m_sx.setString(value);
1534        }
1535
1536        @Override
1537        @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") // all the fun's when sourceClass is null
1538        public <T extends Source> T getSource(Class<T> sourceClass)
1539        throws SQLException
1540        {
1541            if ( null == sourceClass )
1542            {
1543                switch ( m_how )
1544                {
1545                case 1:
1546                    return (T)new StreamSource(m_sx.getBinaryStream());
1547                case 2:
1548                    return (T)new StreamSource(m_sx.getCharacterStream());
1549                case 4:
1550                    sourceClass = (Class<T>)StreamSource.class;
1551                    break;
1552                case 5:
1553                    sourceClass = (Class<T>)SAXSource.class;
1554                    break;
1555                case 6:
1556                    sourceClass = (Class<T>)StAXSource.class;
1557                    break;
1558                case 7:
1559                    sourceClass = (Class<T>)DOMSource.class;
1560                    break;
1561                }
1562            }
1563            return m_sx.getSource(sourceClass);
1564        }
1565
1566        @Override
1567        public <T extends Result> T setResult(Class<T> resultClass)
1568        throws SQLException
1569        {
1570            return m_sx.setResult(resultClass);
1571        }
1572    }
1573
1574    /**
1575     * Class that will mock an {@code SQLXML} instance, returning only binary or
1576     * character stream data from a byte array or string supplied at
1577     * construction.
1578     */
1579    public static class SQLXMLMock implements SQLXML
1580    {
1581        private String m_chars;
1582        private byte[] m_bytes;
1583
1584        public SQLXMLMock(String content)
1585        {
1586            if ( null == content )
1587                throw new NullPointerException("Null SQLXMLMock content");
1588            m_chars = content;
1589        }
1590
1591        public SQLXMLMock(byte[] content)
1592        {
1593            if ( null == content )
1594                throw new NullPointerException("Null SQLXMLMock content");
1595            m_bytes = content;
1596        }
1597
1598        @Override
1599        public void free() throws SQLException { }
1600
1601        @Override
1602        public InputStream getBinaryStream() throws SQLException
1603        {
1604            if ( null != m_bytes )
1605                return new ByteArrayInputStream(m_bytes);
1606            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1607                "SQLXMLMock.getBinaryStream");
1608        }
1609
1610        @Override
1611        public OutputStream setBinaryStream() throws SQLException
1612        {
1613            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1614                "SQLXMLMock.setBinaryStream");
1615        }
1616
1617        @Override
1618        public Reader getCharacterStream() throws SQLException
1619        {
1620            if ( null != m_chars )
1621                return new StringReader(m_chars);
1622            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1623                "SQLXMLMock.getCharacterStream");
1624        }
1625
1626        @Override
1627        public Writer setCharacterStream() throws SQLException
1628        {
1629            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1630                "SQLXMLMock.setCharacterStream");
1631        }
1632
1633        @Override
1634        public String getString() throws SQLException
1635        {
1636            if ( null != m_chars )
1637                return m_chars;
1638            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1639                "SQLXMLMock.getString");
1640        }
1641
1642        @Override
1643        public void setString(String value) throws SQLException
1644        {
1645            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1646                "SQLXMLMock.setString");
1647        }
1648
1649        @Override
1650        @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") // sourceClass==StreamSource is verified
1651        public <T extends Source> T getSource(Class<T> sourceClass)
1652        throws SQLException
1653        {
1654            if ( null != sourceClass && StreamSource.class != sourceClass )
1655                throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1656                    "SQLXMLMock.getSource(" + sourceClass.getName() + ")");
1657            if ( null != m_chars )
1658                return (T) new StreamSource(new StringReader(m_chars));
1659            return (T) new StreamSource(new ByteArrayInputStream(m_bytes));
1660        }
1661
1662        @Override
1663        public <T extends Result> T setResult(Class<T> resultClass)
1664        throws SQLException
1665        {
1666            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
1667                "SQLXMLMock.setResult");
1668        }
1669    }
1670}
